unnormalised: Electoral reforms are crucial for ensuring free, fair, and transparent elections – the very bedrock of our democracy. In India, like anywhere else, these reforms are a continuous process, aimed at addressing emerging challenges and strengthening the democratic process.
normalised: Electoral reforms are crucial for ensuring free, fair, and transparent elections – the very bedrock of our democracy. In India, like anywhere else, these reforms are a continuous process, aimed at addressing emerging challenges and strengthening the democratic process.

unnormalised: What kind of reforms are we talking about? Think about curbing the influence of money and muscle power. For example, stricter regulations on campaign finance, limiting expenditure, and making sure those with criminal records don't find their way into Parliament like some characters straight out of a Prakash Jha film. The Election Commission of India (ECI) plays a monumental role here, working hard to enforce the Model Code of Conduct.

unnormalised: Voter registration is another key area. Making it easier for citizens, especially young people and migrants, to register and exercise their franchise is vital. Initiatives like online registration and special camps in colleges are steps in the right direction. Think of the millions of construction workers who migrate from Bihar to Mumbai; ensuring they can vote is critical.

unnormalised: Other important reforms include addressing issues related to Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT), promoting greater voter awareness, and exploring alternative voting systems, like proportional representation, although that raises its own set of complications.
normalised: Other important reforms include addressing issues related to Electronic Voting Machines (E V M s) and Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (V V P A T), promoting greater voter awareness, and exploring alternative voting systems, like proportional representation, although that raises its own set of complications.

unnormalised: Ultimately, effective electoral reforms are not just about rules and regulations; they require a change in mindset, a commitment from all stakeholders – political parties, civil society, and citizens – to uphold the integrity of the electoral process. Consider the debates in the Constituent Assembly – they knew the importance of a robust electoral system. They would have surely advocated for the ongoing evolution of our electoral practices!
